A7.T1.caption: Table 1: Performance upper bounds for strongly convex objectives with full client participation. Here, absolute constants and polylogarithmic factors are omitted. We further relax the upper bounds of SFL-V2 for an easier comparison.
references: We compare our derived bounds for SFL to other distributed approaches. For simplicity, we let an=1/Nsubscript𝑎𝑛1𝑁a_{n}=1/N in (1) and σn=σsubscript𝜎𝑛𝜎\sigma_{n}=\sigma for all n𝑛n in (6). The result are summarized in Table 1. Since different convergence theories make slightly different assumptions, we clarify them below.

A7.T2.caption: Table 2: Communication and computation comparison between FL, SL, and SFL.
references: We start with the definitions. Let K𝐾K represent the total number of clients involved, p𝑝p denote the aggregate size of the data, and q𝑞q indicate the size of the smashed layer. The rate of communication is given by R𝑅R, while T𝑇T signifies the duration required for a complete forward and backward propagation cycle on the entire model for a dataset of size p𝑝p, applicable across various architectures. The time needed to aggregate the full model is expressed as Tfedavgsubscript𝑇fedavgT_{\text{fedavg}}. The full model’s size is denoted by |W|𝑊|W|, and β𝛽\beta reflects the proportion of the full model’s size that is accessible to a client in SFL, specifically, |WC|=β​|W|subscript𝑊𝐶𝛽𝑊|W_{C}|=\beta|W|. The factor 2​β​|W|2𝛽𝑊2\beta|W| in the communication per client arises from the necessity for clients to download and upload their model updates before and after the training process. These findings are encapsulated in Table 2. It is observed that as K𝐾K escalates, the cumulative cost of training time tends to rise following the sequence: SFL-V2 being less than SFL-V1.
